DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges U.S. Support For Czech Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent congratulations to Vaclav Havel on his election today as president of Czechoslovakia and pledged U.S. support for the rebirth of democracy in the East European nation. The White House said the election of the once dissident playwright ``marks a fitting end to a year of astonishing change in Eastern Europe.'' Bush sent the message from the remote Beeville, Texas, ranch where he was winding up a post-Christmas hunting trip, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Havel, 53, jailed repeatedly over the past two decades for defying Czechoslovakia's communist rulers with his calls for freedom, was elected unanimously to the presidency by the 303 members of Parliament gathered in a medieval castle in Prague earlier today. Fitzwater, in a written statement released in this Gulf of Mexico city where the traveling White House was quartered, said: ``The president has sent a warm message of congratulations to Vaclav Havel upon his election as president of Czechoslovakia. The president noted the strong links between American and Czechoslovak democracy, going back to the creation of the Czechoslovak state in 1918.'' He said Bush ``pledged his commitment to the renewal and strengthening of political, economic and cultural ties between Czechoslovakia and the United States.'' Bush's message, according to the spokesman, said that Havel's election ``is living proof of what Mr. Havel has called the `power of the powerless' to bring about peaceful democratic change.''
